title: Cambridge Public Records Request Log - 2023

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Cambridge Public Records Request Log - 2023
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, this is a request for records related to this agency’s receipt of and response to public records requests. 

For the period from January 1, 2023 through December 31, 2023, please provide all logs and available related details of public records requests received by this office. Responsive materials include those that describe the following details for each public records request received by this office: 
• The name of the requester and the affiliated organization
• The date on which the request was received by this office
• The city department for which the request was intended
• A description of the requested records
• The tracking number assigned by this office to the request
• The date on which the request was closed by this office
• The final disposition of the request, including, if possible, whether the request was fully fulfilled, partially fulfilled, rejected in its entirety, resulted in no responsive documents, or remains open
• Details on exemptions applied to responsive and withheld records
• The number of released pages

Please provide the responsive materials in the form of a spreadsheet (either in CSV or XLS file formats), if possible. 

This request is being made as part of an academic and journalistic project and is not being made for any commercial reason. In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request be fulfilled electronically, via e-mail attachment, the upload link in the footer of this message, or Dropbox, if possible.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Please contact me if your office has any questions about this request. 

Sincerely,

Beryl Lipton

title: Keystone Pipeline Permit Decisions, Environmental Assessments, and Internal Communications (2017-2021)

communications.communication:
Date:  January 12th ,2024
Via Email and Certified Mail:

Headquarters, U.S. Army Corps of Engineers
441 G Street NW
Washington, DC 20314-1000


Subject: FOIA Request - Keystone Pipeline Permit Decisions, Environmental Assessments, and Internal Communications (2017-2021)

Dear U.S. Army Corps of Engineers,

I am submitting this request under the Freedom of Information Act (5 U.S. Code § 552) for access to and copies of records from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers pertaining to the Keystone Pipeline permit. This request specifically targets decision-making processes, environmental assessments, policy implications, internal communications, and interactions with TC Energy or its affiliates during President Donald Trump's administration (January 20, 2017, to January 20, 2021).

Specific Areas of Inquiry:

Permit Processing and Decision Making (2017-2021):

Documentation detailing the processing, review, and decisions regarding the Keystone Pipeline permit.
Communications involving Corps officials and senior administration figures, particularly focusing on the involvement of Secretary of Energy Dan Brouillette.
Environmental Assessments and Impact Reports (2017-2021):

Environmental impact studies and assessments conducted or reviewed by the Corps regarding the Keystone Pipeline.
Internal discussions, memos, or reports addressing environmental concerns or risks.
Internal Communications (2017-2021):

Internal emails, memos, and communications within the Corps regarding the Keystone Pipeline project.
Discussions and correspondence that provide insight into the internal perspectives and debates about the project.
Communications with TC Energy and Affiliates (2017-2021):

Records of communications between the Corps and TC Energy or its affiliates.
Documentation of any meetings or negotiations involving TC Energy representatives.
External Influence and Lobbying (2017-2021):

Records detailing lobbying efforts or attempts to influence the Corps regarding the Keystone Pipeline permit.
Evidence of external entities' influence on the Corps' decision-making processes.
Legal Citations and Compliance:

Department of Justice v. Tax Analysts, 492 U.S. 136, 142 (1989)
Environmental Protection Agency v. Mink, 410 U.S. 73 (1973)
Favish v. National Archives and Records Administration, 541 U.S. 157 (2004)
American Civil Liberties Union v. Department of Justice, 655 F.3d 1 (D.C. Cir. 2011)
Fees and Waiver Request:
Enclosed is a Fee Waiver Request Form, requesting a waiver of all fees as this information is intended for public dissemination, per 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii).

Response Timeframe and Legal Implications:
A response is expected within the statutory 20-day period as mandated by FOIA. Non-compliance or undue delay may result in legal action to enforce FOIA compliance.

Record Keeping for Legal Purposes:
Please assign a unique identifier to this FOIA request and reference it in all related correspondence.

Your prompt and thorough attention to this request is greatly appreciated. I look forward to your comprehensive response.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

Enclosure: Fee Waiver Request Form

title: Keystone Pipeline Permit Decisions, Environmental Assessments, and Communications (2017-2021)

1000 Independence Ave., SW

Subject: FOIA Request - Keystone Pipeline Permit Decisions, Environmental Assessments, Internal Communications (2017-2021)

Dear Office of FOIA Services,

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act (5 U.S. Code § 552), I, Jordan Lassiter, request access to and copies of records from the U.S. Department of Energy related to the Keystone Pipeline permit during President Donald Trump's administration (January 20, 2017, to January 20, 2021). This request specifically targets decision-making processes, environmental assessments, policy implications, internal communications, and interactions with TC Energy or its affiliates.

Specific Areas of Inquiry:

Communication with TC Energy and Affiliates (2017-2021):

Records of communication between the Department of Energy and TC Energy or its affiliates regarding the Keystone Pipeline permit.
Documentation of meetings, correspondences, or negotiations involving TC Energy representatives and Department officials.
High-Level Decision Making Involving Key Personnel (2017-2021):

Communications, including internal emails and memos, involving President Trump, Secretary of Energy Dan Brouillette, and other key officials regarding the Keystone Pipeline permit.
Records of meetings and discussions about the Keystone Pipeline, highlighting the involvement of Secretary Brouillette and other key officials.
Environmental Impact and Concerns (2017-2021):

Environmental impact reports, particularly those expressing significant risks or concerns.
Internal discussions, emails, or memos indicating the overriding of environmental concerns for political or economic considerations.
External Influence and Lobbying (2017-2021):

Records of lobbying efforts by external entities in favor of the Keystone Pipeline.
Evidence of influence on decision-making processes by these entities, including internal correspondence.
Legal Citations and Compliance:

Department of Justice v. Tax Analysts, 492 U.S. 136, 142 (1989)
Environmental Protection Agency v. Mink, 410 U.S. 73 (1973)
Favish v. National Archives and Records Administration, 541 U.S. 157 (2004)
American Civil Liberties Union v. Department of Justice, 655 F.3d 1 (D.C. Cir. 2011)
Fees and Waiver Request:
Enclosed is a Fee Waiver Request Form. I request a waiver of all fees as the information requested is intended for public dissemination and not for commercial use, per 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii).

Response Timeframe and Legal Implications:
A response is expected within the statutory 20-day period as outlined in FOIA. Non-compliance or undue delay may result in legal action to enforce compliance with FOIA regulations.

Record Keeping for Legal Purposes:
Please assign a unique identifier to this FOIA request and reference it in all related correspondence for accurate record-keeping and potential legal proceedings.

Thank you for your attention to this important matter. I await your prompt and comprehensive response.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

Enclosure: Fee Waiver Request Form

title: Comparative Analysis of Office Resources During Obama and Trump Administrations

communications.communication:
Office of the Special Envoy to Monitor and Combat Anti-Semitism
U.S. Department of State
2201 C Street NW
Washington, DC 20520
Email: SEAS@state.gov

Re: New Freedom of Information Act Request

Dear Office of the Special Envoy,

Subject: Comparative Analysis of Office Resources During Obama and Trump Administrations

I am writing to submit a new request under the Freedom of Information Act (5 U.S.C. § 552), focusing on the differences in allocation of resources, including funding and staffing, to the Office of the Special Envoy to Monitor and Combat Anti-Semitism during the Obama and Trump administrations.

Request for Records:

    Budget and Funding Comparison: Detailed records of annual budgets, funding allocations, and expenditures for specific programs, initiatives, or research, during both the Obama and Trump administrations, for a comparative financial analysis.

    Staffing and Resource Allocation: Records on staffing levels, roles, and resource distribution within the Office across these two presidential terms, including changes in staffing numbers and positions.

    Impact and Effectiveness Assessment: Internal assessments, evaluations, or analyses regarding the effectiveness of the Office's strategies and resource utilization in combating anti-Semitism throughout these presidential terms, with a focus on comparative analysis.

Legal Citations:
In accordance with Department of Justice v. Tax Analysts, 492 U.S. 136, 142 (1989), and NLRB v. Robbins Tire & Rubber Co., 437 U.S. 214, 242 (1978), a diligent search for records and a detailed justification for any withholdings under FOIA exemptions are expected.

Fees and Costs:
Please notify me of any applicable fees in advance. I am requesting a fee waiver for this FOIA request as the information is intended for public dissemination and not for commercial use, as per 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii).

Enclosure:
Attached is a completed Fee Waiver Request Form, outlining the justification for the waiver under FOIA guidelines.

Denial of Request:
If denied, in whole or in part, a written explanation with specific FOIA exemptions is expected, as required by National Archives and Records Administration v. Favish, 541 U.S. 157 (2004).

Publication Warning:
Be advised that the contents of your response, along with this request, will be made public. This information may also be used in court proceedings to ensure compliance with the FOIA.

Record of Correspondence:
This request and all responses will be part of the official record. Please assign a new FOIA request number for this submission.

I look forward to your timely response within the statutory 20-day period.

Sincerely,
Jordan Lassiter

title: Erik van Sabben (31 January 1972 - 16 January 2009)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Erik van Sabben (31 January 1972 - 16 January 2009)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records mentioning, relating to, or generated as a result of investigation or inquiry into Dutch businessman Erik van Sabben (31 January 1972 - 16 January 2009). Van Sabben was the business development manager of Dubai's TTS International. A recent news report by Volkskrant (https://volkskrant.nl/nieuws-achtergrond/aivd-speelde-cruciale-rol-bij-sabotage-kernprogramma-iran~ba24df9f/) named him as a Dutch intelligence asset.

Van Sabben's death was widely reported (https://www.thenationalnews.com/uae/engineer-who-helped-build-the-maqta-bridge-1.553285). As such, privacy concerns under FOIA Exemptions 6 and 7 are voided, as are any concerns under the Privacy Act.

If any part of these documents are exempt from disclosure, please be sure to review and release all reasonably segregable nonexempt portions of responsive documents, as the FOIA requires.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Matthew Petti

title: Request for the Trump Administration Period (2017-2021)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Request for the Trump Administration Period (2017-2021)
communications.communication:
General Services Administration
FOIA Request
1800 F Street NW
Washington, DC 20405


Dear General Services Administration,

Subject: Detailed Records Request for the Trump Administration Period (2017-2021)

I am writing to submit a request under the Freedom of Information Act (5 U.S.C. § 552), for specific records from the General Services Administration during the Trump administration, specifically from January 20, 2017, to January 20, 2021.

Request for Records:

    Real Estate Transactions and Leases: Records of all real estate transactions, leases, and agreements involving the GSA during the specified period, focusing on significant or unusual transactions.

    Contracts and Procurements: Details of major contracts and procurements, including changes in procurement policies or practices and information on large infrastructure projects or technology acquisitions.

    GSA’s Role in Presidential Transition: Documentation related to the GSA's activities during the 2020 presidential transition, including communications and transition resource allocation.

    Internal Policies and Directives: Internal policies, guidelines, or directives issued or revised by the GSA, especially those impacting federal property management, building security, and procurement procedures.

    Environmental and Sustainability Initiatives: Information on any environmental or sustainability initiatives, including green building practices and energy efficiency programs, undertaken or revised during this period.

    Security Measures and Protocols: Records of changes or updates to security measures and protocols for federal buildings, including any directives or communications related to heightened security measures.

    GSA's Interactions with the White House and Other Agencies: Correspondence and records of interactions between the GSA and the White House, as well as other federal agencies, regarding property management, federal space allocation, and logistical support.

    Budget Allocations and Financial Reports: Detailed budget allocations, financial reports, and expenditure breakdowns for the GSA during this timeframe, highlighting any significant budgetary changes or anomalies.

Legal Citations:
Pursuant to Department of Justice v. Tax Analysts, 492 U.S. 136, 142 (1989), and NLRB v. Robbins Tire & Rubber Co., 437 U.S. 214, 242 (1978), I expect a thorough search for records and a detailed justification for any withholdings under FOIA exemptions.

Fees and Costs:
Please inform me of any fees in advance. I request a fee waiver for this FOIA inquiry, as the information is for public dissemination and not for commercial use, per 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii).

Enclosure:
Attached is a Fee Waiver Request Form, justifying the waiver under FOIA guidelines.

Denial of Request:
If denied, in whole or in part, please provide a written explanation citing specific FOIA exemptions, as mandated by National Archives and Records Administration v. Favish, 541 U.S. 157 (2004).

Publication Warning:
The contents of your response and this request will be made public, and may be used in legal proceedings to ensure FOIA compliance.

Record of Correspondence:
This request and all associated responses will form part of the official record. Please assign a new FOIA request number to this submission.

I await your timely response within the 20-day statutory period.

Sincerely,
Jordan Lassiter

Enclosure: Fee_Waiver_Request_Form.pdf

Butler County Recorder's Office
130 High Street

Re: Public Records Request Under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 149.43

ATTENTION: DETAILED LEGAL REQUEST FOR RECORDS - STRICT COMPLIANCE REQUIRED

Dear Butler County Recorder,

This request, made under the Ohio Public Records Act (Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 149.43), is crafted for precise legal compliance and clear understanding, as it may be subject to judicial review.

Requester: Jordan Lassiter, Jordan@Lassiter.eu

Subject: Comprehensive Request for Records Related to Property at 9172 W Meadow Dr, West Chester, OH 45069

communications.subject: Re: Fwd: Ohio Open Records Law Request: Comprehensive Request for Records Related to Property at 9172 W Meadow Dr, West Chester, OH 45069
communications.communication:
Mr. Lassiter,

The public records request for the property at 9172 West Meadow Drive,
West Chester, Ohio 45069, has been brought to my attention.
I appreciate your inquiry regarding the information you are seeking.
Unfortunately, the scope of duties assigned to the county recorder, as
outlined in the Ohio Revised Code 317, is limited to recording documents
and making them publicly available for constructive notice. The county
recorder is not authorized to determine the legal sufficiency of
documents or conduct a title search. Attached to this communication are
the recorded documents on file for the property since its platting in
2019. 
For a comprehensive title search, I recommend engaging the services of
a reputable title company. They possess the expertise needed to assess
legal sufficiency and provide a thorough title search for the property
in question.
Additionally, if you are seeking information related to property tax
assessments, values, and valuation methods, I suggest contacting the
county auditor. The Chief Deputy, Lori Sullivan, can assist you with
this specific inquiry. She is reachable at
sullivanl@butlercountyohio.org.
For details regarding building permits and zoning requests, please
reach out to the Butler County Building & Zoning Department. The
director, David Fehr is available at David.fehr@bcohio.us and will be
able to provide information and assistance in these areas.
I hope this guidance leads you to the information you are seeking. If
you have further questions or require additional assistance, feel free
to reach out. Thank you.





>>>

title: Public Records Request for Data on School Policing (Whately Police Department)

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Public Records Request for Data on School Policing (Whately Police Department)
communications.communication:
To whoever it may concern: 

This letter constitutes a request pursuant to the Public Records Act, G.L. c.66, §10, for public records in the custody of your school district. Under the Criminal Justice Reform Act,  school districts and law enforcement agencies must “specify the manner and division of responsibility for collecting and reporting the school-based arrests, citations and court referrals of students to the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education” (DESE).   DESE began collecting data on school-related arrests in the 2018-19 school year. In the 2019-20 school year, DESE has expanded that collection to include data on all referrals to law enforcement.  DESE has defined these terms as follows, borrowing the same definitions used by the U.S. Department of Education since its 2009 Civil Rights Data Collection.  

A school-related arrest “[r]efers to an arrest of a student for any activity conducted on school grounds, during off campus school activities (including while taking school transportation), or due to a referral by any school official. All school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”  

A referral to law enforcement “[i]s an action by which a student is reported to any law enforcement agency or official, including a school police unit, for an incident that occurs on school grounds, during school-related events, or while taking school transportation, regardless of whether official action is taken. Citations, tickets, court referrals, and school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”   


I request the following public records, as defined in G. L. c. 4, § 7 (twenty-sixth): 

1.	An extract of your records management system or database that includes each school-related arrest and each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022 school year (up until the day the records are produced). Specifically, we request an extract of the database to include the following columns:
a.	Date of arrest or referral to law enforcement
b.	Time of arrest or referral to law enforcement
c.	Charge (or charges)
d.	Whether the individual(s) was arrested or referred to law enforcement
e.	Sex of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
f.	Age of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
g.	Race of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
h.	Ethnicity of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
i.	Disability status of the individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
j.	Whether the individual arrested or referred to law enforcement is a student at the school.
k.	Name of arresting officer, if applicable, and 
l.	Badge number of the arresting officer or the officer that referred the youth to law enforcement, as applicable.

2.	If such an extract of the database in question 1 is not possible, please provide school incident reports on each school-related arrest and referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022 school year (up until the day the records are produced). 

3.	A copy of any active standard operating procedures developed with the police department and/or other law enforcement agencies regarding police placement or activity in your corresponding school;  and,

4.	Any records instructing or informing police personnel of, or otherwise describing data reporting requirements and procedures for complying with G.L. c. 71 § 37P(b).

5.	The cost to the school district of assigning a school resource officer to each school; and, 

6.	The total number of school resource officers and total number of guidance counselors for each school in your district for school years 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and,

7.	The total number and a brief description of 911 calls from schools in your district to local police departments conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022, and, 

8.	A description of the proposed budget for mental, social, or emotional health support personnel for the school district.

As this request involves a matter of public interest and will not be used for any commercial purpose, we ask that all fees associated with this request be waived pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(k). The purpose of this request is to determine whether your school district and police department are complying with their reporting obligations under the Criminal Justice Reform Act.  “The public has an interest in knowing whether public servants are carrying out their duties in an efficient and law-abiding manner.”    

It would be ill-advised to impose a fee for data that your school district may have failed to report in violation of statutory and regulatory duty.  Moreover, as you know, municipalities with a population of over 20,000 may not assess a fee for the first 2 hours of time spent searching for, compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. Finally, pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(i), a records access officer shall assess no fee greater than the lowest hourly rate of a person capable of compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. In the event that a charge is incurred for this request which you will not waive, please so indicate and include an itemization of estimated good faith costs.
 
Please provide public records to a requestor in an electronic format unless the record is not available in an electronic format. G.L.c. 66, § 6A(d). 

The Public Records Act requires that you comply with this request within ten (10) business days following receipt. If you believe that documents or data responsive to any request herein is not public record and thus not subject to disclosure, please set forth in writing the specific reasons for such assertion, including the specific exemption or exemptions that you believe apply.  To the extent that you determine that records need to be redacted in order to be produced under any law protecting the privacy of named individuals, please do so rather than withholding them in their entirety.

If you have any questions about this request, or need additional time to respond, please contact me by phone at (617)-373-5862 or by email at k.stathulis@northeastern.edu. Thank you in advance for your prompt response to this request.
	
Sincerely, 


Katherine Stathulis, Esq.
Center for Public Interest, Advocacy, and Collaboration
Northeastern University School of Law

6.	The total number of school resource officers and total number of guidance counselors for each school in your district for school years 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and,

7.	The total number and a brief description of 911 calls from schools in your district to local police departments conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022, and,

The Public Records Act requires that you comply with this request within ten (10) business days following receipt. communications.communication:
To whoever it may concern: 

This letter constitutes a request pursuant to the Public Records Act, G.L. c.66, §10, for public records in the custody of your school district. Under the Criminal Justice Reform Act,  school districts and law enforcement agencies must “specify the manner and division of responsibility for collecting and reporting the school-based arrests, citations and court referrals of students to the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education” (DESE). A referral to law enforcement “[i]s an action by which a student is reported to any law enforcement agency or official, including a school police unit, for an incident that occurs on school grounds, during school-related events, or while taking school transportation, regardless of whether official action is taken. title: Public Records Request for Data on School Policing (West Bridgewater Police Department)

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Public Records Request for Data on School Policing (West Bridgewater Police Department)
communications.communication:
To whoever it may concern: 

This letter constitutes a request pursuant to the Public Records Act, G.L. c.66, §10, for public records in the custody of your school district. Under the Criminal Justice Reform Act,  school districts and law enforcement agencies must “specify the manner and division of responsibility for collecting and reporting the school-based arrests, citations and court referrals of students to the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education” (DESE).   DESE began collecting data on school-related arrests in the 2018-19 school year. In the 2019-20 school year, DESE has expanded that collection to include data on all referrals to law enforcement.  DESE has defined these terms as follows, borrowing the same definitions used by the U.S. Department of Education since its 2009 Civil Rights Data Collection.  

A school-related arrest “[r]efers to an arrest of a student for any activity conducted on school grounds, during off campus school activities (including while taking school transportation), or due to a referral by any school official. All school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”  

A referral to law enforcement “[i]s an action by which a student is reported to any law enforcement agency or official, including a school police unit, for an incident that occurs on school grounds, during school-related events, or while taking school transportation, regardless of whether official action is taken. Citations, tickets, court referrals, and school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”   


I request the following public records, as defined in G. L. c. 4, § 7 (twenty-sixth): 

1.	An extract of your records management system or database that includes each school-related arrest and each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022 school year (up until the day the records are produced). Specifically, we request an extract of the database to include the following columns:
a.	Date of arrest or referral to law enforcement
b.	Time of arrest or referral to law enforcement
c.	Charge (or charges)
d.	Whether the individual(s) was arrested or referred to law enforcement
e.	Sex of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
f.	Age of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
g.	Race of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
h.	Ethnicity of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
i.	Disability status of the individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
j.	Whether the individual arrested or referred to law enforcement is a student at the school.
k.	Name of arresting officer, if applicable, and 
l.	Badge number of the arresting officer or the officer that referred the youth to law enforcement, as applicable.

2.	If such an extract of the database in question 1 is not possible, please provide school incident reports on each school-related arrest and referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022 school year (up until the day the records are produced). 

3.	A copy of any active standard operating procedures developed with the police department and/or other law enforcement agencies regarding police placement or activity in your corresponding school;  and,

4.	Any records instructing or informing police personnel of, or otherwise describing data reporting requirements and procedures for complying with G.L. c. 71 § 37P(b).

5.	The cost to the school district of assigning a school resource officer to each school; and, 

6.	The total number of school resource officers and total number of guidance counselors for each school in your district for school years 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and,

7.	The total number and a brief description of 911 calls from schools in your district to local police departments conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022, and, 

8.	A description of the proposed budget for mental, social, or emotional health support personnel for the school district.

As this request involves a matter of public interest and will not be used for any commercial purpose, we ask that all fees associated with this request be waived pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(k). The purpose of this request is to determine whether your school district and police department are complying with their reporting obligations under the Criminal Justice Reform Act.  “The public has an interest in knowing whether public servants are carrying out their duties in an efficient and law-abiding manner.”    

It would be ill-advised to impose a fee for data that your school district may have failed to report in violation of statutory and regulatory duty.  Moreover, as you know, municipalities with a population of over 20,000 may not assess a fee for the first 2 hours of time spent searching for, compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. Finally, pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(i), a records access officer shall assess no fee greater than the lowest hourly rate of a person capable of compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. In the event that a charge is incurred for this request which you will not waive, please so indicate and include an itemization of estimated good faith costs.
 
Please provide public records to a requestor in an electronic format unless the record is not available in an electronic format. G.L.c. 66, § 6A(d). 

The Public Records Act requires that you comply with this request within ten (10) business days following receipt. If you believe that documents or data responsive to any request herein is not public record and thus not subject to disclosure, please set forth in writing the specific reasons for such assertion, including the specific exemption or exemptions that you believe apply.  To the extent that you determine that records need to be redacted in order to be produced under any law protecting the privacy of named individuals, please do so rather than withholding them in their entirety.

If you have any questions about this request, or need additional time to respond, please contact me by phone at (617)-373-5862 or by email at k.stathulis@northeastern.edu. Thank you in advance for your prompt response to this request.
	
Sincerely, 


Katherine Stathulis, Esq.
Center for Public Interest, Advocacy, and Collaboration
Northeastern University School of Law

I request the following public records, as defined in G. L. c. 4, § 7 (twenty-sixth): 

1.	An extract of your records management system or database that includes each school-related arrest and each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022 school year (up until the day the records are produced). Specifically, we request an extract of the database to include the following columns:
a.	Date of arrest or referral to law enforcement
b.	Time of arrest or referral to law enforcement
c.	Charge (or charges)
d.	Whether the individual(s) was arrested or referred to law enforcement
e.	Sex of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
f.	Age of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
g.	Race of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
h.	Ethnicity of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
i.	Disability status of the individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
j.	Whether the individual arrested or referred to law enforcement is a student at the school.
k.	Name of arresting officer, if applicable, and 
l.	Badge number of the arresting officer or the officer that referred the youth to law enforcement, as applicable.

2.	If such an extract of the database in question 1 is not possible, please provide school incident reports on each school-related arrest and referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022 school year (up until the day the records are produced). 

3.	A copy of any active standard operating procedures developed with the police department and/or other law enforcement agencies regarding police placement or activity in your corresponding school;  and,

4.	Any records instructing or informing police personnel of, or otherwise describing data reporting requirements and procedures for complying with G.L. c. 71 § 37P(b).

5.	The cost to the school district of assigning a school resource officer to each school; and, 

6.	The total number of school resource officers and total number of guidance counselors for each school in your district for school years 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and,

7.	The total number and a brief description of 911 calls from schools in your district to local police departments conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022, and, 

8.	A description of the proposed budget for mental, social, or emotional health support personnel for the school district.

As this request involves a matter of public interest and will not be used for any commercial purpose, we ask that all fees associated with this request be waived pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(k). The purpose of this request is to determine whether your school district and police department are complying with their reporting obligations under the Criminal Justice Reform Act.  “The public has an interest in knowing whether public servants are carrying out their duties in an efficient and law-abiding manner.”    

It would be ill-advised to impose a fee for data that your school district may have failed to report in violation of statutory and regulatory duty.  Moreover, as you know, municipalities with a population of over 20,000 may not assess a fee for the first 2 hours of time spent searching for, compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. Finally, pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(i), a records access officer shall assess no fee greater than the lowest hourly rate of a person capable of compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. In the event that a charge is incurred for this request which you will not waive, please so indicate and include an itemization of estimated good faith costs.
 
Please provide public records to a requestor in an electronic format unless the record is not available in an electronic format. G.L.c. 66, § 6A(d). 

The Public Records Act requires that you comply with this request within ten (10) business days following receipt. If you believe that documents or data responsive to any request herein is not public record and thus not subject to disclosure, please set forth in writing the specific reasons for such assertion, including the specific exemption or exemptions that you believe apply.  To the extent that you determine that records need to be redacted in order to be produced under any law protecting the privacy of named individuals, please do so rather than withholding them in their entirety.

If you have any questions about this request, or need additional time to respond, please contact me by phone at (617)-373-5862 or by email at k.stathulis@northeastern.edu. Thank you in advance for your prompt response to this request.
	
Sincerely, 


Katherine Stathulis, Esq.
Center for Public Interest, Advocacy, and Collaboration
Northeastern University School of Law

communications.communication:
To whoever it may concern: 

This letter constitutes a request pursuant to the Public Records Act, G.L. c.66, §10, for public records in the custody of your school district. Under the Criminal Justice Reform Act,  school districts and law enforcement agencies must “specify the manner and division of responsibility for collecting and reporting the school-based arrests, citations and court referrals of students to the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education” (DESE). A referral to law enforcement “[i]s an action by which a student is reported to any law enforcement agency or official, including a school police unit, for an incident that occurs on school grounds, during school-related events, or while taking school transportation, regardless of whether official action is taken. 1. a.	Date of arrest or referral to law enforcement

e.	Sex of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement

j.	Whether the individual arrested or referred to law enforcement is a student at the school.

l.	Badge number of the arresting officer or the officer that referred the youth to law enforcement, as applicable.

Finally, pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(i), a records access officer shall assess no fee greater than the lowest hourly rate of a person capable of compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. In the event that a charge is incurred for this request which you will not waive, please so indicate and include an itemization of estimated good faith costs.

title: Public Records Request for Data on School Policing (Silver Lake Police Department, Silver Lake)

communications.communication:
To whoever it may concern: 

This letter constitutes a request pursuant to the Public Records Act, G.L. c.66, §10, for public records in the custody of your school district. Under the Criminal Justice Reform Act,  school districts and law enforcement agencies must “specify the manner and division of responsibility for collecting and reporting the school-based arrests, citations and court referrals of students to the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education” (DESE).   DESE began collecting data on school-related arrests in the 2018-19 school year. In the 2019-20 school year, DESE has expanded that collection to include data on all referrals to law enforcement.  DESE has defined these terms as follows, borrowing the same definitions used by the U.S. Department of Education since its 2009 Civil Rights Data Collection.  

A school-related arrest “[r]efers to an arrest of a student for any activity conducted on school grounds, during off campus school activities (including while taking school transportation), or due to a referral by any school official. All school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”  

A referral to law enforcement “[i]s an action by which a student is reported to any law enforcement agency or official, including a school police unit, for an incident that occurs on school grounds, during school-related events, or while taking school transportation, regardless of whether official action is taken. Citations, tickets, court referrals, and school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”   


I request the following public records, as defined in G. L. c. 4, § 7 (twenty-sixth): 

1.	An extract of your records management system or database that includes each school-related arrest and each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022 school year (up until the day the records are produced). Specifically, we request an extract of the database to include the following columns:
a.	Date of arrest or referral to law enforcement
b.	Time of arrest or referral to law enforcement
c.	Charge (or charges)
d.	Whether the individual(s) was arrested or referred to law enforcement
e.	Sex of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
f.	Age of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
g.	Race of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
h.	Ethnicity of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
i.	Disability status of the individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
j.	Whether the individual arrested or referred to law enforcement is a student at the school.
k.	Name of arresting officer, if applicable, and 
l.	Badge number of the arresting officer or the officer that referred the youth to law enforcement, as applicable.

2.	If such an extract of the database in question 1 is not possible, please provide school incident reports on each school-related arrest and referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022 school year (up until the day the records are produced). 

3.	A copy of any active standard operating procedures developed with the police department and/or other law enforcement agencies regarding police placement or activity in your corresponding school;  and,

4.	Any records instructing or informing police personnel of, or otherwise describing data reporting requirements and procedures for complying with G.L. c. 71 § 37P(b).

5.	The cost to the school district of assigning a school resource officer to each school; and, 

6.	The total number of school resource officers and total number of guidance counselors for each school in your district for school years 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and,

7.	The total number and a brief description of 911 calls from schools in your district to local police departments conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022, and, 

8.	A description of the proposed budget for mental, social, or emotional health support personnel for the school district.

As this request involves a matter of public interest and will not be used for any commercial purpose, we ask that all fees associated with this request be waived pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(k). The purpose of this request is to determine whether your school district and police department are complying with their reporting obligations under the Criminal Justice Reform Act.  “The public has an interest in knowing whether public servants are carrying out their duties in an efficient and law-abiding manner.”    

It would be ill-advised to impose a fee for data that your school district may have failed to report in violation of statutory and regulatory duty.  Moreover, as you know, municipalities with a population of over 20,000 may not assess a fee for the first 2 hours of time spent searching for, compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. Finally, pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(i), a records access officer shall assess no fee greater than the lowest hourly rate of a person capable of compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. In the event that a charge is incurred for this request which you will not waive, please so indicate and include an itemization of estimated good faith costs.
 
Please provide public records to a requestor in an electronic format unless the record is not available in an electronic format. G.L.c. 66, § 6A(d). 

The Public Records Act requires that you comply with this request within ten (10) business days following receipt. If you believe that documents or data responsive to any request herein is not public record and thus not subject to disclosure, please set forth in writing the specific reasons for such assertion, including the specific exemption or exemptions that you believe apply.  To the extent that you determine that records need to be redacted in order to be produced under any law protecting the privacy of named individuals, please do so rather than withholding them in their entirety.

If you have any questions about this request, or need additional time to respond, please contact me by phone at (617)-373-5862 or by email at k.stathulis@northeastern.edu. Thank you in advance for your prompt response to this request.
	
Sincerely, 


Katherine Stathulis, Esq.
Center for Public Interest, Advocacy, and Collaboration
Northeastern University School of Law

As this request involves a matter of public interest and will not be used for any commercial purpose, we ask that all fees associated with this request be waived pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(k). The purpose of this request is to determine whether your school district and police department are complying with their reporting obligations under the Criminal Justice Reform Act.  “The public has an interest in knowing whether public servants are carrying out their duties in an efficient and law-abiding manner.”    

It would be ill-advised to impose a fee for data that your school district may have failed to report in violation of statutory and regulatory duty.  Moreover, as you know, municipalities with a population of over 20,000 may not assess a fee for the first 2 hours of time spent searching for, compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. Finally, pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(i), a records access officer shall assess no fee greater than the lowest hourly rate of a person capable of compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. In the event that a charge is incurred for this request which you will not waive, please so indicate and include an itemization of estimated good faith costs.
 
Please provide public records to a requestor in an electronic format unless the record is not available in an electronic format. G.L.c. 66, § 6A(d). 

The Public Records Act requires that you comply with this request within ten (10) business days following receipt. If you believe that documents or data responsive to any request herein is not public record and thus not subject to disclosure, please set forth in writing the specific reasons for such assertion, including the specific exemption or exemptions that you believe apply.
